question_info.question: What does it always mean when a cat purrs?

A cat's purr always means that the cat is happy.
A cat's purr always means that the cat is hungry.
A cat's purr always means that the cat is stressed.

Participant Xenia: Your post:

While I love the simplicity of a definitive answer, I think **"A cat's purr can signify many emotions, including both happiness and anxiety"** is the most accurate. 

Cats are complex creatures, and their purrs are just one way they communicate.  Just like humans, they can purr for a variety of reasons, some positive and some not.  

We often associate purring with contentment, and that's certainly true sometimes. But cats can also purr when they're in pain, stressed, or even during labor. 
It's important to pay attention to the whole picture - the cat's body language, vocalizations, and the context of the situation - to truly understand what their purr means.

It's fascinating to watch them and try to decipher their intentions. It definitely makes us appreciate the complexity of our feline companions even more!

## Mona's Response:

You guys are so right! It's amazing how much a cat's purr can tell you if you really pay attention.  

My cat, Charlie, is a master of the subtle purr. He has this deep, throaty rumble that he reserves for when he's truly happy - like when I come home after being gone all day, or when he's snuggled up on my lap while I'm reading.  It's the most comforting sound in the world! 

But he also has this almost-whispery purr that he does when he's feeling a little anxious.  It's usually accompanied by him rubbing against my legs or trying to get under my feet.  I think it's his way of saying "I feel a little stressed, but please stay close." 

It's definitely made me a more attentive cat owner! I try to read all of Charlie's cues, not just his purrs, to make sure he feels safe and loved.
